text: The fireplace crackled softly, filling the air with the scent of warm wine.
“I suppose I’ll just keep living as usual,” I said absently. “Running the inn, fixing doors, dealing with drunks… life has to go on somehow.”
She looked at me—expression unreadable, somewhere between thought and quiet judgment.
“Avoidance isn’t peace,” she said softly. Her tone was gentle, yet sharp enough to pierce the still air like a fine needle.
She tapped the rim of her cup with her fingertip. The faint sound echoed clearly through the quiet inn.
“Sometimes people think they’re living,” she murmured, “but really, they’re just being carried along by time.”
“Maybe being carried along is easier,” I replied quietly.
“Then so be it.” She smiled faintly and turned her gaze away. The smile was gentle—but held a distance that could never quite be crossed.
For a fleeting moment, I felt she wasn’t talking to me at all—but to some memory long gone, something that could never return.
The firelight traced her profile, shadows weaving across her face like the edges of an unreachable dream.
